Journal Story: Â  Â After many months of physical and mental preparation, Iâ€™m once again heading out on the Appalachian Trail tomorrow. Â Iâ€™m doing a non traditional flip flop thru hike starting just north of Mt Greylock near the mass./Vermont border heading south to Springer, then flipping back north to my starting point and heading north to Katadin. Â Iâ€™ve almost had too much time to prep for this hike and have really been chomping at the bit to get going as Iâ€™ve waited for the weather to moderate a bit. Â I should be able enjoy some relative solitude on the trail as the majority of thru hikers are still way down south. Â Gonna take it relatively easy first few weeks as I drop some weight and get my trail legs. Â Looking forward to this adventure,Â LP

Day 1Phelps Avenue North Adams mile marker 1595.0Father Tom Campground mile marker 1580.8Â 
Total miles 14.2Â  Â  First day back on trail in three years. Â  I decided a while back that I should kick off this thru hike with a bit of an epic start, Mount Greylock. My oldest son Andrew dropped me off at the end of Phelps Avenue in North AdamsÂ at 10:20 AM, I gave him a hug and said goodbye. Â Those first few steps on trail felt like jumping out of an airplane for the first time parachuting. Â Mount Greylock welcomed me with a 5.8 mile climb that was really more than I bargained for. Â If I had not trained for the past two months my body wouldâ€™ve quickly wilted on todayâ€™s hike. Â I reaced the top and quickly realized that it was too cold to hang out but the views were limitless on a perfectly Â cloudless day. Â To my chagrin as I began the dissent I soon realized that the southside of the mountain was largely in the shade. Â The result was 3 miles of steady ice and snow sometimes referred to as an ice luge. Â I was lucky enough to only fall once and it was relatively controlled and did not result in injury although my Smartwater bottle slid down the trail about 50 feet. Â I told myself during all my training hikes I will come to regret starting where I did trying to tackle MT Greylock in very early spring, but I did tackle it. Â However the 14.8 miles that I did felt more like 20+. Â I Wearily hiked into Cheshire and hoped the town campground would be available to camp at as I really couldnâ€™t have gone any further. Â Luckily it was and I quickly set up camp.My first dinner was a misadventure resulting in a tuna couscous soup which was very unpalatable. Â I crawled into my tent and sleeping bag and attempted to do this trail journal, however both of my feet, my left hand,my calves, and my right hamstring weâ€™re all attempting to cramp! Â Well this hikeÂ was a bit more than I was prepared for. I was proud to have finished it and be so quickly reminded what a day on AT is like.

Day 2Father Tom Campground mile marker 1580.8Kay wood shelter mile marker 1569.2Total miles 11.6Â  All day today I felt the hangover from my hike yesterday and a poor nights sleep at father Tomâ€™s campground. Â It was called getting down to 26Â° and the spotlights from the public works department shined on me like a convict trying to escape prison. Â I was determined to stay in my sleeping bag as long as possible but I simply donâ€™t sleep well on the trail and ended up getting out of my bagÂ at 7 AM. Â Being out of practice in terms of breaking camp it seem to take forever but I was able to start hiking byÂ 8 AM. Â The climb out of Cheshire was relatively easy but my legs were heavy and non-responsive. Â I managed to push through and get the first climb out of the way and it was a relatively easy 5 to 6 more miles into Dalton mass. Â To my great disappointment businesses in Dalton mass that serve food are closed on Easter Sunday, so I enjoy the fine diningâ€˜s of Cumberland Farms. Â Again unpalatable. Â Somehow my mileage ended me with having to choose to do a short day of 11 or one approaching 20 miles. Â I was honestly tempted to shoot for 20 but my body was telling me otherwise. Â Iâ€™m honestly feeling pretty good Iâ€™m feeling my knees on the down hills and I really donâ€™t want to create an overuse injury this early in the hike. Â The first 10 miles tomorrow looks very flat so I may try to make up a few miles tomorrow as the weather continues to look perfect until at least Saturday. Â Should be 7-8 degrees warmer tonight so hoping I wonâ€™t get as Chilled as last night.

Day 3Kay Wood shelter mile marker 1569.2Upper goose pond cabin mile marker 5151.6Total miles 17.6Â  Â  Today started with the dread of getting out of my sleeping bag as the wind was howling and the windchillâ€˜s were in the 20s. Â However, havenâ€™t gone into my sleeping bag early in the evening last night I wasnâ€™t able to last pastÂ 6:30 AMÂ and hit the trailÂ at 7:24 AM. Â Luckily I was able to hike out of the really bad wind and managed to start what turned out to be a very pleasant first 10 miles of the day. Â The highlight being the views from Warner Hill of Mt. Greylock Â in the distance. Â The weather remain chilly and windy, but thatâ€™s my preferred weather when hiking hard. Â After stopping at October mountain shelter for a quick break the terrain the next seven miles proved more taxing, but I was in no rush, so just pushed through it. Â On the downside during one of my water breaks today I apparently left my camp shoes where I braked, as I keep them with my water filter on the outside of my pack. Â A minor inconvenience as I can get another pair until thisÂ upcoming Sunday. Â Iâ€™m camping on the front porch of upper Goosepond cabin tonight so that should be pretty cool. Â A bunch of firsts today as I met a fellow hiker who is doing a bunch of section hikes on the AT from Connecticut, I met my first trail maintainer of the hike and saw my first garter snake. Â Hoping with the bigger mileage day today I sleep a bit better tonight, itâ€™s been pretty rough the first two nights. Â All in all a great day minus the camp shoes disappearing.

day 4Uppergoose pond cabin mile marker 1551.6Mt. Wilcox south sheltersMile marker 1535.6Total miles 16.0Â  Â  Fun fact, Iâ€™m pretty sure I heard a pair owls mating Â last night. Â Last night was actually the best night of sleep Iâ€™ve had so far. Â I left Goosepond cabinÂ at 7:24 AMÂ and proceeded for the next 7 miles over some pretty unremarkable terrain that was not the most enjoyable. Â I had resigned myself to the fact that today may just be one of those days but then I hiked into Tryingham. Â For the next 4 miles my spirits were lifted has the trail transformed into some thing different that it had been in the morning. Â Boardwalks through wetlands, cow pastures and cornfields. Â I stopped for lunch at a campsite, however upon departing that campsite I hit a climb that just kicked my ass. Â Itâ€™s grade was just enough to leave me totally gassed afterwards and made the rest of the day a bit of a struggle. Â I mindlessly knocked out the miles bound to get to my destination and upon arriving found the water source was dry! Â I had almost no water and eventually figured out that I need to hike .3 miles further south on the AT to find the next water source, then back track back. Â It couldâ€™ve been worse,but that was a real kick in the balls when you show up to camp and just want to stop hiking. Day 5Â Mt. Wilcox south sheltersMile marker 1535.6Glen Brook sheltermile marker 1516.0Total miles 19.6Â  Â  It has been said that long-distance hikers have a higher propensity for soiling themselves than the general population. Â The extreme physical exertion coupled with visits into towns to eat fat and greasy foods can often lead to intestinal instability. Â Despite not having eaten any town food on this trip so far I managed to deposit a half a can of wet dog food in my longjohns during my morning piss! Â This is kind of a worst nightmare situation in the middle of the woods and if it werenâ€™t for my one luxury item that I have been question on by other hikers I wouldâ€™ve been in big trouble. Â My little pack of make up remover wipes that I carry to clean up at the end of the day really saved me. Â It was a lengthy cleanup process and my poor longjohns are now buried on the side of Mount Wilcox mountain hopefully to be never found again.Â  Â I did some hiking as well today I actually did 19.6 miles which was my longest day and ended with a 3.4 mile climb up towards Mount Everett that was super tough. Â I was exhausted and dehydrated so my main focus was not falling as it was actually kind of a dangerous climb. Â There was about a 5 mile Valley hike today that was nice and flat but totally exposed to the sun with no water sources, which left me suffering from symptoms of dehydration. I try to drink the best I can but I sweat so heavily that itâ€™s just tough to keep up. Â I may have a chance to go to Salisbury tomorrow for some real food but after today and the ongoing intestinal issues I had throughout the day I may just skip it. Â Sleeping in another shelter all by myself again tonight and I will sleep well!

Day 6Glen Brook shelter mile marker 1516.0Cobble rd Salisbury 1502.5Daily miles 13.5Â  Â  After a fairly solid nights sleep last night I awoke shortly after first light moving quickly to keep warm in the cold mountain morning air. Â I was met with Mt. Everett almost immediately out of camp and neither my legs or lungs were warmed up yet to tackle its short but steep ascent. Â Up I slowly went only to find a very steep descent on the other side... Â Mt race was up next as my legs began to feel spry. Â With more gradual dimensions I made quick work of her. Â Lastly, Bear mountain, I havw descended the north side of this mountain a couple times and itâ€™s Notoriously steep.The climb wasnâ€™t Â long, but it required all four limbs as my trekking poles hung from wrists and I grabbed for rock and tree alike to continue my progress. Â The descent down Bear was longer than I had remembered, but I finally arrived in Salisbury. Â Straight to LaBonneâ€™s Market for chicken cutlet grinder, two chicken legs, fruit salad, cool ranch Doritos and two Arizona ice teas! Â My eyes were bigger than my stomach, but luckily Iâ€™m staying town at Vanessa Bretonâ€™s house who hosts thru hikers for a very reasonable rate. Â Hot shower, off my feet for the night and gonna eat the rest of my food tonight. Â Iâ€™ll be back on trail in the morning right I hit the bakery around the corner for coffee and a pastry when openÂ at 7:30am. ğŸ˜

Day 7AT on cobble rd. SalisburyÂ Mile marker 1502.5Ceasar Brook campsiteÂ Mile marker 1483.9Daily miles 18.6Total miles 111.1Â  Â After a peaceful evening at Vanessa Bretonâ€™s humble and historic home, I treated myself to coffee and a croissant at Sweet Williams around the corner from her house this morning. Â Unfortunately they didnâ€™t open till 730 so I didnâ€™t get back on trail until 815. Â The hiking from Saulsberry to Falls Village was very stress-free although I did bring back a lot of memories of my 2016 hike. Â This was preceded by two days hiking through Connecticut after a week off recovering from Lyme disease. Â When I return to the trail I just couldnâ€™t get back into the headspace that Iâ€™ve been in for the last 11 weeks. Â The emotional turmoil in those two days after making it so far and working so hard it was a really difficult thing to except, but it was what it was. Â I tried to put those negative feelings behind me and quickly did when I got to Randâ€™s View, which in opinion is hands down the best view in CT! I took a short break there to soak in the view and then continued on in to Falls Village and finally to RT7. Â Saulsberry Rt7 was truly easy hiking and I covered 10 miles quickly, but then came the next 8.5 miles... Â The highlight of my campsite tonight is the privy! Â Itâ€™s a small wooden box with the toilet seat on it and thatâ€™s it, no walls no doors just a toilet in the middle of the woods. Â Of course I had to use it and it was great, but maybe not in a downpour though..

Day 8Ceasar CampgroundÂ Mile marker 1483.9CT 341 Kent CTÂ Mile Marker 1470.2Daily miles 13.7Â  Â  My bladder woke me upÂ at 5:30amÂ and I decided to start my day by headlamp. Â I contined on the last four miles trying to get to CT341 byÂ 1:30Â when my dad and stepmom had agreed to pick me up. Â I arrivedÂ at 1:28Â only to find out they were running 30 minutes late..ğŸ˜¡. Â Hot shower, Japanese food and sleep was the rest of the day as I didnâ€™t even bother unpacking my backpack.

Day 9Zero at homeÂ  Â A much needed zero today after 8 days of borderline overdoing it for roughly 125 miles. Â I received my 2nd Covid vaccination earlier today, went shed shopping with my wife and hosted my brother and sister in law for a early dinner. Â Â Â Â I would like to give a shout out to all the trail maintainers in MA. and Ct., they were definitely busy already in Ct. this spring as I witnessed a lot of fresh sawdust on the trail as a fall hurricane came through last year that caused major blow downs throughout the state. Â I heard NY got it even worse, guess Iâ€™ll find out this upcoming week.Iâ€™ll be heading back to Kent, Ct. in the morning and will be in NY by the end of the day. I lost 7 pounds first 8 days and that rapid weight loss will continue for the next 3-4 weeks. Â Gonna be a long stretch before I see any loved ones again, but Iâ€™m looking forward to the journey.

Day 10New York State of MindCT 341 Kent mile marker 1470.2Telephone pioneers shelter mile marker 1448.7Daily miles 21.5Â Â  Â  My alarm went offÂ at 5:45 AMÂ and I quickly got in the shower, ran downstairs put on Â all my hiking clothes and packed up my backpack. Â I drove and my wife was the passenger on the way to Kent. Â She dropped me off and a hug and kiss later I hiking up Mt. Algo. Â I canâ€™t camp that early, I just canâ€™t. Â Problem was next shelter was 9 miles away and rain was in Â the forecast. Â I manned up and pushed on. Â As I had heard the blow downs in NY are far worse than MA and CT. Â Most were manageable except one I had to crawl under and there were prickers on the ground. Â I ended up reaching my destinationÂ around 6:15pmÂ and quickly changed out of my wet clothes and got my chores done. Â I was nice getting in to NY, a state I havenâ€™t hiked since 2016. Day 11Â Takeout Tuesday!Telephone pioneers shelter mile marker 1448.7RPH shelter mile marker 1431.9Daily miles 16.8Â  Â  Â Today was a pretty unremarkable hiking day. Â The things that really stand out in retrospect was that the sun didnâ€™t come out till aboutÂ 1 PMÂ and the aphids did come out. Day 12Â Quit bugging me!RPH shelter mile marker 1431.9Hemlock Springs campsite mile marker 1408.9Daily miles 23.0
Â  Â  Todayâ€™s hikeÂ between 7:15 AM and 1 oâ€™clockÂ was fairly slow due to train and a strong sun. Â For some reason I thought all morning that I only had 20 miles to do today and then at 1oâ€™clock I rechecked my guidebook and realized I still had 12 miles to go. Day 13Ainâ€™t no hero, give me a Nero!Hemlock Springs campsite mile marker 1408.9Bear mountain bridge mile marker 1406.5Daily miles 2.4 milesTotal miles 188.5Â Â  Â After unsuccessfully managing to keep my daily mileage as low as i planned, heavy rain in the forecast and accruing 60 miles in the past three days I decided to take a Nero in Fort Montgomery NY. Â My trail legs are starting to come into form, but I donâ€™t want to push them too hard just yet. Â I was awake at 5:30 AM this morning and hiking by Â 6:20. Â I made the short but steep descent down to Bear Mountain Bridge as the many cars raced by. Â I decided to walk to Bear mountain bridge motel, enjoying the remnants of history just yards from the sidewalk were the remains of buildings that had been under heavy attack by British forces in 1777.Â  Â  I managed to find hey small little breakfast place where I was able to get hot coffee and a breakfast wrap. Â I was super early for my room for the night but luckily there was a vacancy and the owners found me on the front porch and let me write into my roomÂ at 9:30Â in the morning. Day 14The highs and lows of thru- hiking.Bear Mountain Bridge mile marker 1406.5Stealth camp mile marker 1388.5Daily miles 18 total milesÂ 206.5Â  Â  I was dropped off at the rotary a Fort MontgomeryÂ at 7:50 AM. Â My hiking clothes were soaking wet and it was 37Â° out. Â I rang them out the best I could and took a deep breath as I put them on. Â Took extra care to keep my few dry items dry, packed up the rest to be dried at a later date. Â The morning was very slow as the train and up and down mountains with no Ridgewalk just up and then down and repeat for over three hours. Â I did have the psychological boost of crossing over into New Jersey which pushed me on as the daylight hours dwindled. Â I finally made it to camp close toÂ 7 PMÂ and to my surprise I had my first camp me of the hike. Journal Story: Day 16â€œYou so strongâ€Wawayanda Shelter mile marker 1364.6High point shelter 1340.7Â Daily miles 24.1Â  Â  I hit the trail early this morning at 6:45, as I reached a descent known as â€œstarirway to heavenâ€ and began to go down my first highlight of the occurred. Â I passed an out of breath middle aged Spanish woman ascending, she looked at me muttered, â€œYou so strongâ€ and nothing else. Â This stroke of my ego after being humbled daily by a footpath was a real boost!Â Â  It was followed by arriving at heavenâ€™s hill farm just as they opened! Â Large coffee, 3 apple cider donuts and two chocolate chip cookies for the road! Â This section today featured a beautiful boardwalk walk and a walk through a bird sanctuary, both totally flat!! Â My legs felt incredibly strong all day, although my knees took a while to warm up after some tough downhills yesterday. Â New Jersey may be the most underrated state on the AT.

Day 17
Gypâ€™s tavern and grill and a black bearHigh Point shelter mile marker 1340.7
Campsite mile marker 1317.1Daily miles 23.6Â  Â  Â I left campÂ at 6:40 AMÂ and hiked up to the Overlook, which gave a great view of the High Point Veterans Memorial. Â Â  Â  I left thereÂ at 2:45Â and had the option of going 3.6 miles to a shelter or 7.6 miles to a campsite. Â I got hit with a Bree shower on the way to the shelter and there was more rain in the forecast so I hunker down at the shelter for a bit with two female hikers. It was a small shelter and a bit crowded to stay so after I realized the forecasted rain wasnâ€™t really going to hit I took offÂ around 6 PM. Day 18
Feet prepare your selves weâ€™re entering PA.campsite mile marker 1317.1Episcopalian church of the mountain mile marker 1295.9Daily miles 22.0Â  Â  I intended to get up super early today since I was hiking into town but my camp spot was so nice on top of a ridge with mountain winds blowing all night but not going my tent. Day Â 19Cold front a comingPresbyterian church on the mountain mile marker 1295.9Leroy Smith Shelter mile marker 1276.0Daily miles 20.1Â Total miles 319.0Â  Â  After the night in the lien to behind the Presbyterian Church of the mountain fellowship house where there were loud noises of traffic for my 80 and three very bright light shining on me all night I was up around 545 to the singing of the birds. Â I hiked out of Delaware water gapÂ at 6:53Â and met my one big climb of the day which I took slowly as my legs still werenâ€™t loose. Â The climb took about an hour with a couple decent views and I was soon excited to find out the rocks in Pennsylvania didnâ€™t start until about 8.5 miles into my day. Â But when they did start they did so abruptly as the change in trail was was very evident. Â The last 11 miles today and probably all tomorrow and maybe some of Friday is the worst section of rocks Pennsylvania has to offer. In a way, Â Iâ€™m glad to get them over with opposed to the noboâ€™s who have to hike the state in dread of this section. Â  I can get it over with in the first few days Iâ€™m going to enjoy the rest of the state knowing this part is over. Â I had some major food disappointments in Delaware water gap that I was locally able to make up for today in wind gap. Two scrambled eggs crispy hashbrowns and wheat toast and a grilled cheese sandwich with bacon and a bag of chips and a half a pickle and three glasses of Dr Pepper. Â The forecast today had originally been terrible but as I approached Windgap I only got hit with about 10 minutes of rain but the real story was the wind. Â By the time I got down to town the wind was blowing 40 to 50 mph and the temperature has dropped into the 40s. Â I finished my meal and bought two Poweradeâ€˜s at the Sunoco where I plan to set up and try to get a hitchhike back to the trail head. Â As I went out by the roadside in my little sock on your running shorts and rain jacket my legs and ass quivered in the high intensity winds and wind chill. Â Luckily a fellow named Adam picked me up after about 3 minutes. Â Brought me up to the trail head and drop me off in my 4 1/2 mile hikes to the shelter was mostly on the one side of the mountain. Â The on top of the mountain the wind had to be blowing 50 to 60 miles an hour and I had no choice but to hike as quickly as I could on the rocks just to stay warm enough. Â Not ideal hiking conditions but definitely memorable ones! Â Supposed to get down to 28 tonight just hoping the wind dies down...

Day 20A cold wind came to townLeroy Smith shelter mile marker 1276.0Lehigh gap mile marker 1259.6Daily miles 16.4
Â  Â  So last night turned out to be very cold and I was forced into my sleeping bag byÂ 6:30 PMÂ just to stay warm. Â The wind blew all night and the sound of sleep on the shelter roof began around 445. Â It took about 30 minutes for my feet and fingers to warm up and I kept all my gear onÂ until 10 AMÂ when I was finally able to put away my gloves I kept the rest of my gear on all day. Â I decided last night that I was going to stay at a hostel in Palmerton tonight to give my spirit and body a break from the cold as the winds are predicted to continueÂ until tomorrow. Â The next two days look to warm up a bit and Iâ€™m hoping to put in some pretty good miles the owners going to shuttle me back to the trail headÂ around 8 AM. Â Saw myself in the mirror for the first time in over a week and the physical transformation which occurs hiking 20 miles a day is simply remarkable. Â I already hardly recognize my own body in the mirror. Â Scary thought when I will probably lose another 20 pounds in the next month...

Day 22Â
